Award.AwardTitle: RIDIR: Collaborative Research: Computational and Historical Resources on Nations and Organizations for the Social Sciences (CHRONOS)

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Award.AbstractNarration:
This project will collect, process, and analyze millions of U.S. government records concerning international relations, develop tools to explore these records, and make all of them available on a single website with an Application Programming Interface. The project will demonstrate how computational techniques can aid both qualitative and quantitative social science research on a range of areas of major public interest, expanding knowledge about terrorism, intelligence, international trade and aid. Among its broader impacts, it will improve the infrastructure available for multidisciplinary research and teaching, and also give citizens, journalists, and civil society organizations much better access to information about international relations. Participating student researchers will both learn about -- and contribute to -- practical methods to keep government transparent and accountable in the age of "big data."

The exponential growth in digitized or "born digital" documents will make such methods increasingly important in years to come. To meet the challenge, the team will draw on new work in Natural Language Processing, customize existing tools that turn text into data, and develop new tools for use with historical documents. They will employ Named Entity Recognition techniques to extract names of people, countries, and organizations, enabling users to track the absolute and relative frequency of mentions in large digital archives. Through Topic Modeling, they will summarize the thematic content and show how the most important subjects change over time. And Social Network extraction will allow them to reveal the informal relationships that shape policy from day-to-day. By bringing together all of this quantitative declassified data in a single platform, the project will advance work by political scientists as well as scholars of communications and social networks who seek to understand agenda-setting, power, and influence within and between organizations. The platform will enable researchers to test fundamental questions in IR theory, such as whether policymakers generally speak to one another in terms of "state security," as realists insist, or "international norms," as liberalism assumes. It will allow users to shift between different levels of analysis, from an aggregate view of whole archives, to filtered subsets of metadata, to the specific words in one sentence that produced a single data point. It will bring together quantitative and qualitative approaches to research in international relations, and make both more transparent, rigorous, and replicable.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The foreign policy of the United States is of profound interest to scholars and citizens alike. They want to understand the history of the US's relations with other countries, how power and priorities have changed, and what has been accomplished (and what has not!) by American diplomatic efforts. Studying these important matters is difficult however, because obtaining documents that record foreign policy-making decisions can be hard---or even impossible. Partly, this is because there is no "one stop shop" for viewing and downloading diplomatic records: (declassified) records exist invarious forms in various places, and often in different formats. Partly also, it is because the information we want to extract from those documents---for example the people and places they name, or the themes they cover---can usually only be obtained through very laborious reading. Our NSF funded project aimed to solve both of these problems.


First then, we built the world?s largest database of declassified documents. And we put it all on the web, for researchers or the public to use. Our web archive now contains eight different collections, over three million documents, and around 720GB of raw data. It focusses on US generated documents, but also includes some other corpora which we think are important for understanding world diplomacy. At the core are two large datasets. First, the Foreign Relations of the United States (FRUS) which are curated, "important" documents obtaining to US foreign policy from 1861 to 1985. Second, the Central Foreign Policy File (CFPF) collection, which includes full text of the "cables? (essentially secure messages) sent between US diplomatic posts and the State Department?s headquarters in Washington, DC from 1973 to 1979. Beyond these, we have added transcripts from the telephone calls of Secretary of State Kissinger and other American, British and Brazilian data collections. This information is served up to the world via a web portal, where anyone can search for specific documents of interest, browse the archives and analyze them. This can be found at http://history-lab.org/.


But we do more than simply serve up documents. We also provide "meta-data"---that is, data about the data---for interested users. In our NSF work, we focussed on identifying people and places, so that documents can be linked and searched with respect to those "named entities". That way, scholars and interested members of the public can, for example, see how different individuals or countries wax or wane in importance over time. In addition, from the text data, we have automatically coded "themes" in policy-making overtime. Users can see how these develop and evolve, as international and domestic politics changes.


Our project---to get theoretically "publicly available" documents actually publicly available---will extend well beyond the funding period itself. Our web portal, and the database itself, will be added to as we find new collections or clean and refine old ones.
